results.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
results.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_primary.name: Shadow play
constellations_primary.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

results.description:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.
description_for_label:

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Reko Rennie, Carlo Zeccola, Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey and Film Camp
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Reko Rennie, Carlo Zeccola, Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey and Film Camp
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this work by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

The work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Director: Reko Rennie

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

Produced by Trials

Director of Photography: Sherwin Akbarzadeh

Featuring

Sensei Master: Adam Briggs (Yorta Yorta)

Students: Caine Muir (Yorta Yorta and Wati Wati), Inala Cooper (Yawuru), James Saunders (Gundtijmara and Wiradjuri), Joe Bell (Yorta Yorta), Kelvin Onus King (Gunditjmara), Kimmie Lovegrove (Ngarrindjeri), Mila Rennie Galvin (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay),Reko Rennie (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay), Sermsah Pepi Bin Saad (Nyikina), Shane Mankitya Cook (Guwa (Koa) and Wulli Wulli), Talahiva Rose (Gomeroi), Vicky Frowd (Wiradjuri)

results.title: The Theatre of War
results.credit_line: The Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for Young Australian Artists is created in partnership with Professor Cav. Simon Mordant AO and Catriona Mordant AM, the City of Melbourne, John Allsopp from Web Directions, and ACMI
results.material_description: three channel video installation, surround sound, 10 min duration
results.brief_description: Theatre of War draws parrallels between Homer ancient Greek epic and the ongoing modern conflicts through performance and the moving image.
results.description:
Homer’s epic poem The Iliad begins nine years into the bitter Trojan War between the Achaeans (Greeks) and the city of Troy. Similarly, Stanislava Pinchuk began filming The Theatre of War in 2023 – nine years following Russia’s invasion and annexation of the Ukrainian territory of Crimea in 2014.

Across three global locations, three different performances draw on the oral traditions from which The Iliad evolved. In antiquity, the poem was presented over three days and accompanied by a lyre. The music helped performers, known as rhapsodes, recall the poem’s verses by matching the rhyming structure to the beat.

At the tomb of Homer on the Greek island of Ios, two local teens uphold that musical tradition, keeping the beat. One wears a football jersey emblazoned with kleos (glory). Visitors to Homer’s tomb endlessly rearrange the loose stones, a fitting metaphor for the shifting nature of storytelling, through time and translation. The Mediterranean Sea, where Ios lies between Greece and Troy (present-day Hisarlik in Türkiye), is also considered a ‘theatre of war’ because of the deadly passage migrants make through its waters.

A Ukrainian soldier training with British, Canadian and Australians forces in Salisbury, UK adds his voice. He is preparing to fight for his country in Copehill Down, a mock village built to practise urban warfare.

In Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Slavic polyphonic singers rehearse and perform in a literal war theatre, where during the city’s siege (1992-1995) art became a form of resistance, most notably with the staging of Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot by Susan Sontag.

Just as The Iliad contains gruesome descriptions of death on the battlefield, the artwork focuses on both the vitality and vulnerability of bodies in contemporary ‘theatres of war’.

Stanislava Pinchuk filmed at Operation Kudu in the United Kingdom as the official war artist commissioned by the Australian War Memorial in 2023.

About The Iliad

The Iliad was written around 800 BCE and like The Odyssey, is attributed to Homer, about whom little is known beyond the fact that his was the name attached in antiquity by the Greeks themselves to the poems.

The Acheans (Greeks) have held the city of Troy under siege for nine years. Achilles, the strongest Greek warrior is furious at his compatriot Agamemnon, who has laid claim to a Trojan woman previously given to Achilles as a spoil of war. He refuses to fight, causing the near defeat of the

Greek army. When Achilles’ friend Petroclus is killed by the Trojan prince Hector, Achilles focuses his rage on Hector and returns to the battle to kill him. The poem ends with Achilles allowing Hector’s father to take his son’s body back to Troy for burial.

Translator of The Iliad, Emily Wilson writes, “The limitless wrath of Achilles can only end once he recognises that no absolute, permanent victory is ever possible. Everyone must bear unbearable losses, for which no compensation could ever be enough. In the end we all lose. Our best hope is to accept partial, temporary limits on conflict, accepting human companionship and community as our only, always inadequate compensation for the pervasive experience of loss.”

Artist biography

Stanislava Pinchuk’s work explores the changing topographies of war and conflict zones through drawing, installation, tattooing, film, and sculpture. Pinchuk surveys the ways in which landscape holds the memory of political events and the violation of human rights. Her source materials, such as data,

documentation and detritus are collected through fieldwork. Pinchuk’s critical practice reconsiders perceptions of geopolitical borders, migration, climate catastrophe and nuclear crises.

Recent curated exhibitions include: Manifesta 14, Prishtina, Kosovo, and FREE/STATE, Adelaide Biennial of Australian Art. Pinchuk’s artwork and publishing archives are held in numerous Australian and international private and public collections.

Pinchuk was born in Ukraine in 1988. She graduated from the University of Melbourne with a double major in Art History and Philosophy. She lives and works in Sarajevo.
description_for_label: Homer’s epic poem The Iliad begins nine years into the bitter Trojan War between the Achaeans (Greeks) and the city of Troy. Similarly, Stanislava Pinchuk began filming The Theatre of War in 2023 – nine years following Russia’s invasion and annexation of the Ukrainian territory of Crimea in 2014.

results.title: The Australian ballet - Corroboree
results.brief_description: ‘Corroboree’ is both a record of the world premiere of the famous ballet created in Australia, and a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the rehearsal, design and preparation that went into the production. Inspired by composer John Antill’s best known work, the ballet was sponsored by the Arts Council of Australia and choreographed by Rex Reid. Performed by the National Theatre Ballet Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, ‘Corroboree’ is a striking illustration of some of the ways in which white Australia has imagined and expropriated Australian First Nations cultures.

results.title: Mongolian Princess costume from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description:
From seller: A Mongolian Princess costume worn in the 1987 multi Oscar-winning drama The Last Emperor. This stunning costume was worn when the 15 year-old Pu-Yi (Wu Tao) wed’s the ‘old’ government chosen first wife and Empress, 17-year old Wan Jung.
The multi-layered costume consists of a thick white quilted gown with ties to the front, a red rayon brocade under robe overprinted in gold with panels in mulberry green and gold appliqué, high padded shoulders, tall collars, and cuffs trimmed in grey Astrakhan and Mongolian lambswool, and finally a waistcoat in maroon velvet and green brocade, overprinted in gold trimmed with antique fabric appliqués on the front and back panels. There are no sizes marked on this wonderful costume and it remains in excellent condition.
This comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Postcard from Tunis
results.brief_description: The central theme of ‘Postcard from Tunis’ is writing itself - its histories, its inscriptions and its relevance to the human-computer interface. This is explored in a personal, audiovisual portrait of Tunis, the home of my family-in-law. I designed and programmed the unique interface so that it echoes an actual visit, where you can’t help learning a few Tunisian words and with time, starting to read written Arabic. Although the work was designed for adults, children have shown a strong affinity with it.

results.title: [The funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey]
results.brief_description:
This film contains documentary footage of the state funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey, which took place on 30 May, 1951 in Melbourne, Victoria.

The film captures the funeral cortege as it proceeds along Swanston Street, with crowds of people lining the streets and buildings. The flag-covered casket is accompanied by a military band, soldiers and dignitaries. Significant public figures marching in the cortege include Prime Minister Robert Menzies, Governor-General William McKell, Governor of Victoria Sir Dallas Brooks and Chief Justice of the High Court Sir John Latham.

The film includes wonderful footage of Swanston Street from a high vantage point with the Shrine of Remembrance in the distance. There are also great shots of soldiers marching together, military horses, people gathered in front of the Melbourne City Baths and a couple watching on atop the facade of the ‘W.H. Terry Memorial Hall’.

An estimated 300,000 people turned out to watch the funeral procession, which travelled from the Shrine of Remembrance, along St Kilda Road, and up Swanston Street to College Crescent, before proceeding by car to Fawkner Crematorium.

Sir Thomas Blamey (24 Jan 1884 – 27 May 1951) was a General in the Australian army and the only Australian to have achieved the rank of Field Marshal.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

Selected Highlights List
00:00:02:00 – Geoffrey and Jean Parsons playing with a Fox Terrier
00:01:12:00 – Wedding of Mary Dowling Woods and John Bedggood
00:02:07:00 – Melbourne Grammar Sports day at the MCG
00:03:52:00 – The Rose family, Aeneas Gunn and Robin Parsons at the Rose family home with dogs
00:05:10:00 – Doug Rose and Aeneas Gunn riding a cow
00:07:34:00 – Steam boat on the Yarra River
00:07:48:00 – Parson family and friends swimming at Dromana beach showing 1930’s swimming costumes
00:08:44:00 Sidney and Susannah Parsons at Dromana Beach
00:09:53:00 – Parsons family doing Acrobats, playing games and making a human tower at Dromana Beach
00:10:55:00 – Bi Planes – VH–UHR, VH-UHS and VH-UAT
00:12:23:00 – Two women and Geoffrey Parsons on a rug in the garden of the family home
00:14:01:00 – Susannah Parsons demonstrating her golfing swing
00:14:52:00 – View of Princes bridge with Flinders Street Railway station in the Background
00:15:20:00 – View towards the Flinders street Fish Market (demolished in 1956)
00:15:26:00 – Steam boats docked on the Yarra river.
00:15:46:00 – Navy ship in the harbour
00:16:06:00 – The shrine of Remembrance (before the gardens were there) and views of Melbourne from its balcony.
00:21:28:00 – View of Collins Street from the roof of the Parson Bros Mill near Spencer street station, showing the 1935 centennial celebrations parade
00:22:45:00 – Sidney Parsons, Robin Parsons and unknown man playing golf
00:23:56:00 - View from the rooftop of Parsons Bros Mill on Collins Street looking up towards the Victorian Railway administration offices on Spencer street and down Flinders Lane.
00:24:20:00 – People lining Nicholson street (near parliament gardens) to watch lavish floats and masked performers.
00:30:56:00 – Parson family members at the beach in Dromana
00:37:24:00 – Doug and Charlie Parsons climbing the sign labelled the highest house in Australia at Hotham Heights and camping trip
00:42:30:00 – Front view of motorbike with side car following on the road in wet weather
00:27:23:00 – Parson brothers, friends and fiancée Jean, on the coast of Cape Shanck.
00:42:59:00 – Jean Parsons (portrait view)
00:43:03:00 – Robin Parsons (portrait view) smoking
00:43:18:00 – 1939 Australian Championship, Kooyong Stadium – John Bromwich and Adrian Quist
00:43:56:00 – Wedding of unknown couple
00:44:42:00 – VH-USQ Cierva C.30A Auto gyro (Gyrocopter)
00:46:37:00 – The Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane off Dromana Beach. Geoffrey Parsons climbing out of the Cockpit. (VH-UNV)
00:47:51:00 – Douglas DC-2 Airliner VH-USY “Bungana” outside Holymans hangar at Melbourne/Essendon airport
00:48:24:00 – Miles M-3 Merlin (VH-UXN) (Came to Australia in 1936)
00:48:41:00 – De Havilland D.H. 86A express (VH-UUB) Loila outside Holymans Hanger at Melbourne Essendon airport
00:53:23:00 – Rifle shooting in the snow at Mount Hotham

description_for_label:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

results.title: Autograph
results.brief_description: One of 6 works selected by AIM director David Atkinson as representing the best interactive work produced by the AIM centre up until 2004. An interactive work focusing on the use of eloquent graphics and innovative interface screen design for navigation. The work deals with themes such as humanity, organics and technology. A beautiful work pioneering elegant design with an innovative interface. Invited for exhibition at the Young Talent Pavilion in MILIA, France in 1995.
